info.author: Steve Luzynski
classifiers: Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries :: Python Modules
info.description:
# Sleepyq2

![GitHub](https://img.shields.io/github/license/sluzynsk/sleepyq2)
![GitHub issues](https://img.shields.io/github/issues/sluzynsk/sleepyq2)
![GitHub release (latest by date)](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/sluzynsk/sleepyq2)


## An asynchronous Python Library for accessing the SleepIQ Cloud.

Much work here based on the efforts of Nate Johnson & his sleepyq library.

### Why a new library?
Ultimately most of what I wanted to add could have been added to the existing sleepyq 0.7.0 library.
However, the author has had PRs open for nearly a year.
I came to the conclusion that he was probably not working on the library any longer.
Since I was going to have to fork to get my additions in place, I thought it would be an opportune moment to refactor
the library along the way. There were always some things about it that bothered me.

Given that my primary use case for this library is to support the SleepIQ
integration for HomeAssistant, a big reason for the massive revamp
was to make it asynchronous (fast!) as well as to expose some
data and new method calls that will make the integration cooler.

It is not particularly backwards compatible with sleepyq, in large part because
nearly every method is async now.

### Installation
The best method is via pip:
```shell script
pip install sleepyq2
```

### API Reference
API documentation is automatically generated by pdoc3 and included in
the html directory.

There's room for improvement and I will work on that when I can.
info.name: Sleepyq2
info.summary: New async client library for SleepIQ Cloud service.
info.html_description:
Sleepyq2

An asynchronous Python Library for accessing the SleepIQ Cloud.

Much work here based on the efforts of Nate Johnson & his sleepyq library.

Why a new library?

Ultimately most of what I wanted to add could have been added to the existing sleepyq 0.7.0 library. However, the author has had PRs open for nearly a year. I came to the conclusion that he was probably not working on the library any longer. Since I was going to have to fork to get my additions in place, I thought it would be an opportune moment to refactor the library along the way. There were always some things about it that bothered me.

Given that my primary use case for this library is to support the SleepIQ integration for HomeAssistant, a big reason for the massive revamp was to make it asynchronous (fast!) as well as to expose some data and new method calls that will make the integration cooler.

It is not particularly backwards compatible with sleepyq, in large part because nearly every method is async now.

Installation

The best method is via pip:

pip install sleepyq2

API Reference

API documentation is automatically generated by pdoc3 and included in the html directory.

There's room for improvement and I will work on that when I can.
